Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Intraosseous Regional Administration of Vancomycin in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: In a randomised controlled trial, 30 patients scheduled for primary TKA were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either 250 mg or 500 mg vancomycin via IORA or 1 g via systemic administration

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether low-dose intraosseous regional administration (IORA) of vancomycin can achieve tissue concentrations comparable to or exceeding those of systemic administration in total knee arthroplasty (TKA)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the tissue concentration of vancomycin, assessed during the procedure

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured through sealed envelopes

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean vancomycin concentration in subcutaneous fat was 14 μg/g in the 250-mg IORA group, 44 μg/g in the 500-mg IORA group, and 3.2 μg/g in the systemic group

Harms.evidence: One patient in the systemic group experienced red man syndrome. No other adverse events were reported
